Computing non-parametric mixing distribution

computemixdist.Rd

Computing non-parametric mixing distribution

computemixdist(v, method = "npnormll", ...)

computemixdist.npnormll(
  v,
  mu0,
  pi0,
  beta,
  order,
  mix = NULL,
  gridpoints = NULL,
  ...
)

computemixdist.npnormcvm(
  v,
  mu0,
  pi0,
  beta,
  order,
  mix = NULL,
  gridpoints = NULL,
  ...
)

computemixdist.npnormad(
  v,
  mu0,
  pi0,
  beta,
  order,
  mix = NULL,
  gridpoints = NULL,
  ...
)

computemixdist.npnormcll(
  v,
  mu0,
  pi0,
  beta,
  order,
  mix = NULL,
  gridpoints = NULL,
  ...
)

computemixdist.nptll(
  v,
  mu0,
  pi0,
  beta,
  order,
  mix = NULL,
  gridpoints = NULL,
  ...
)

computemixdist.npnormllw(
  v,
  mu0,
  pi0,
  beta,
  order = -3,
  mix = NULL,
  gridpoints = NULL,
  ...
)

computemixdist.npnormcvmw(
  v,
  mu0,
  pi0,
  beta,
  order = -3,
  mix = NULL,
  gridpoints = NULL,
  ...
)

computemixdist.npnormadw(
  v,
  mu0,
  pi0,
  beta,
  order = -3,
  mix = NULL,
  gridpoints = NULL,
  ...
)

computemixdist.nppoisll(
  v,
  mu0,
  pi0,
  beta,
  order,
  mix = NULL,
  gridpoints = NULL,
  ...
)

computemixdist.nptllw(
  v,
  mu0,
  pi0,
  beta,
  order = -3,
  mix = NULL,
  gridpoints = NULL,
  ...
)

Arguments

v

a vector of observations
method

An implemented family; see details
...

parameters above passed to the specific method
mu0

A vector of support points
pi0

A vector of weights corresponding to the support points
beta

structual parameter.
order

the parameter for the binned version.
mix

initial mixing distribution.
gridpoints

a vector of gridpoints to evaluate new support points

Details

These functions are used to compute the estimates of a mixing distribution non-parametrically using various methods, with possibly fixed components.

current implemented families are:

  • npnormll : normal density using maximum likelihood (Chapter 3). The default beta is 1.

  • npnormllw : Binned version of normal density using maximum likelihood (Chapter 6). The default beta is 1 and the default order is -3.

  • npnormcvm : normal density using the Cramer-von Mises distance (Chapter 5). The default beta is 1.

  • npnormcvmw : Binned version of normal density using the Cramer-von Mises distance (Chapter 6). The default beta is 1 and the default order is -3.

  • npnormad : normal density using the Anderson-Darling distance (Chapter 5). The default beta is 1.

  • npnormadw : Binned version of normal density using the Anderson-Darling distance (Chapter 6) The default beta is 1 and the default order is -3.

  • nptll : t-density using maximum likelihood (Chapter 3). The default beta is infinity (normal distribution).

  • nptllw : Binned version of non-centrol t-distribution using maximum likelihood. The default beta is infinity (normal distribution) and the default order is -3.

  • npnormcll : the one-parameter normal distribution used for approximating the sample correlation coefficients using maximum likelihood. This does not have a corresponding estimation of zero due to incompleted theory (Chapter 8). There is no default beta. The structure beta is the number of observations.

  • nppoisll : poisson mixture using maximum likelihood. There is no structural parameter, and hence the template will pass beta but this beta will never be referenced.

The default method used is npnormll.

Examples

set.seed(123)
pi0 = 0
data = rnorm(1000, mean = c(0, 2))
system.time(r <- computemixdist(data, pi0 = pi0, method = "npnormll"))

#>    user  system elapsed 
#>   0.023   0.000   0.024 
r

#> $iter
#> [1] 24
#> 
#> $family
#> [1] "npnorm"
#> 
#> $min.gradient
#> [1] -9.528668e-05
#> 
#> $beta
#> [1] 1
#> 
#> $mix
#> $mix$pt
#> [1] 0.0000000 0.1473455 1.9718642 2.9959354
#> 
#> $mix$pr
#> [1] 0.00000000 0.53041976 0.45782007 0.01176017
#> 
#> 
#> $ll
#> [1] 1722.52
#> 
#> $flag
#> [1] "d1"
#> 
#> $convergence
#> [1] 0
#> 
#> attr(,"class")
#> [1] "nspmix"
system.time(r <- computemixdist(data, pi0 = pi0, method = "npnormcvm"))

#>    user  system elapsed 
#>   0.013   0.000   0.013 
r

#> $iter
#> [1] 7
#> 
#> $family
#> [1] "npnorm"
#> 
#> $min.gradient
#> [1] -7.630008e-14
#> 
#> $beta
#> [1] 1
#> 
#> $mix
#> $mix$pt
#> [1] 0.0000000 0.1585935 2.0155947
#> 
#> $mix$pr
#> [1] 0.0000000 0.5386374 0.4613626
#> 
#> 
#> $ll
#> [1] 0.03071343
#> 
#> $flag
#> [1] "d1"
#> 
#> $convergence
#> [1] 0
#> 
#> attr(,"class")
#> [1] "nspmix"
system.time(r <- computemixdist(data, pi0 = pi0, method = "nptll"))

#>    user  system elapsed 
#>   0.083   0.001   0.084 
r

#> $iter
#> [1] 24
#> 
#> $family
#> [1] "npt"
#> 
#> $min.gradient
#> [1] -9.528712e-05
#> 
#> $beta
#> [1] Inf
#> 
#> $mix
#> $mix$pt
#> [1] 0.0000000 0.1473455 1.9718642 2.9959353
#> 
#> $mix$pr
#> [1] 0.00000000 0.53041976 0.45782007 0.01176017
#> 
#> 
#> $ll
#> [1] 1722.52
#> 
#> $flag
#> [1] "d0"
#> 
#> $convergence
#> [1] 0
#> 
#> attr(,"class")
#> [1] "nspmix"
system.time(r <- computemixdist(data, pi0 = pi0, method = "npnormad"))

#>    user  system elapsed 
#>    0.02    0.00    0.02 
r

#> $iter
#> [1] 12
#> 
#> $family
#> [1] "npnorm"
#>

#> [1] -0.0003599591
#>

#> [1] 1
#> 
#> $mix
#> $mix$pt
#> [1] 0.0000000 0.1483473 1.9544469 2.3759327
#> 
#> $mix$pr
#> [1] 0.00000000 0.53095300 0.42321313 0.04583387
#> 
#> 
#> $ll
#> [1] 0.1816632

#> $convergence
#> [1] 0

#> attr(,"class")
#> [1] "nspmix"
system.time(r <- computemixdist(tanh(data), pi0 = pi0, method = "npnormcll", beta = 4))

#>    user  system elapsed 
#>   0.062   0.002   0.064 
r

#> $iter
#> [1] 20
#> 
#> $family
#> [1] "npnormc"

#> [1] -9.461006e-06

#> $beta
#> [1] 4
#> 
#> $mix
#> $mix$pt
#>  [1] -0.97638718 -0.91582602 -0.78103105  0.00000000  0.02847455  0.73497632
#>  [7]  0.84822980  0.95217224  0.97797874  0.98652942  0.99610345  0.99818746
#> [13]  0.99921169  0.99958934
#> 
#> $mix$pr
#>  [1] 7.767531e-05 2.710161e-02 6.047963e-02 0.000000e+00 3.285872e-01
#>  [6] 1.428905e-01 7.813435e-02 1.370084e-01 6.495828e-02 8.528827e-02
